abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA) looks
            at the activities, and processes of cotton ginneries in
            Benin, and examines its equipment, and site location, to
            determine the associated environmental, and socioeconomic
            impacts, so as to propose mitigation measures. Following a
            review of the country's environmental regulatory
            framework, the EA points at the weak environmental
            performance of cotton ginneries, which despite environmental
            legislation, disregard the current regulatory framework.
            Pollution control measures are inefficient, conducive to
            detrimental socioeconomic consequences: vegetative
            degradation, air pollution, inefficient drainage, and
            contaminated effluents, in addition to oil spills, and noise
            disturbances. Measures to mitigate adversity call for the
            creation of an environmental management committee, to
            establish, and validate the cotton ginneries environmental
            plan of action, set in place environmental units, and
            formulate pilot pollution control programs. The cotton
            ginneries at Savalou, and Bohicon should be permanently
            closed, proposing to transform Savalou into a museum, and,
            Bohicon, into a cotton gin training school, following the
            building's restoration. Modification of chimneys,
            drainage, and canalization, as well as soundproof works, and
            appropriate effluents discharge, should be implemented at
            existing cotton ginneries, to reduce emissions, prevent
            flooding, and reduce noise disturbances from power engines.
            Capacity building, and training should be provided to
            enforce environmental measures, equipment should be
            adequately maintained, and public health surveillance ensured.
